thread.title: Winner, winner: Windjammers, Mariners, Panthers prevail in late-season play
thread.title_full: Winner, winner: Windjammers, Mariners, Panthers prevail in late-season play

author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Staff)
title: Winner, winner: Windjammers, Mariners, Panthers prevail in late-season play
text:
High school boys and girls soccer Winner, winner: Windjammers, Mariners, Panthers prevail in late-season play Oceanside's King, Camden Hills' Anderson earn hat tricks By Staff | Oct 14, 2015 
It was a banner day for Midcoast high school soccer squads on Tuesday, Oct. 12 as all four teams in action on the pitch netted late-season victories. 
On wet fields from the rain earlier in the day, the Camden Hills boys and girls prevailed over Messalonskee of Oakland, while the Oceanside and Medomak Valley boys earned wins over Nokomis of Newport and Morse of Bath, respectively. 
The following is a recap of reported results: 
Girls soccer 
Camden Hills 9, Messalonskee 0 
At Oakland Oct. 12, the Windjammers sailed to a 9-0 win over the host Eagles. Camden Hills led 5-0 at halftime. 
Leading the No. 1, unbeaten Windjammers on offense were Bryn Anderson (3 goals), Eliza Roy (assist), Kassie Krul (goal), Emma Gutheinz (2 assists), Charlotte Messer (2 goals, assist), Izzy Gutheinz (2 goals), Elizabeth Cummons (assist), Eliza Roy (goal), Taylor Johnson (assist) and Eve Gutheinz (assist). 
Camden Hills held a 21-8 edge in shots and a 4-2 advantage in corner kicks. Jana Spieker made eight saves in net for the Windjammers. 
Windjammer coach Meredith Messer said the Eagles were without their starting goaltender, who was out with a concussion, but that they are “glad that she will be able to come back and finish the season for them.” 
“We scored a lot of goals and played a lot of people, but the defense today was outstanding,” coach Messer said. “Brynne Wrona and Claire Pierce, along with Grace Blackwell and Erin Dowd, worked together as a unit and didn't let any long balls over the top today. I was happy to see how they are coming together at the end of our season. We are excited to play Mount Ararat on Thursday and complete our first regular season in Class A." 
In the Maine Principals' Association Heal Point Standings for Class A North, Camden Hills (12-0-1, 152.2449 points) is first in the 14-team region. The top 10 teams qualify for the playoffs. 
Boys soccer 
Oceanside 5, Nokomis 3 
At Newport Oct. 12, the Mariners sailed to a convincing win. Oceanside led 5-0 at halftime, with many substitutes seeing a great deal of time on the field in the second half. 
Andrew King had three goals and two assists in the win for the visitors, while Christian Straka added two goals and Uriah Thongsophaphone one assist. 
John Wilcox, Jared Gail and Connor Bowman creased the net for Nokomis. 
Oceanside held a 12-6 edge in shots. Coby Dorr made nine saves in goal for the Mariners, while Nick Bolliger made one save in net for the Warriors. 
In the Maine Principals' Association Heal Point Standings for Class B North, Oceanside (8-2-2, 85.7908 points) is third, while Ellsworth (10-0-1, 118.2908 points) is first in the 18-team region. The top 12 teams qualify for the playoffs. 
Camden Hills 3, Messalonskee 0 
At Rockport Oct. 12, the Windjammers blanked the visiting Eagles en route to their ninth win. Camden Hills led 2-0 at halftime. 
Kienan Brown scored two goals and assisted on a goal by Garrison Looke to pace the Camden Hills offense. 
Lucas Boetsch made two saves on six shots in net for the Windjammers, while Dylan Jones made eight saves on 16 shots in goal for the Eagles. 
"It was a wet, sloppy day and we didn't play our best, but we played well enough to win,” said Camden Hills coach Ryan Hurley. “We'll look to regroup and put together an excellent performance for our last game of the regular season against Mount Ararat on senior day this Thursday." 
In the Maine Principals' Association Heal Point Standings for Class A North, Camden Hills (9-2-2, 104.4898 points) is third, while Lewiston (13-0, 148.3673 points) is first in the 18-team region. The top 12 teams qualify for the playoffs. 
Courier Publications' sports staff can be reached by email at sports@villagesoup.com or by phone at 594-4401.
